verses.text: I have spoken these things to you so that you will not fall away.
verses.comment: Jesus warns His disciples so that their faith will be steadfast in times of trial, foreseeing persecution yet giving them encouragement. This prepares the community for tribulations, emphasizing perseverance in truth.

verses.text: They will put you out of the synagogues. Indeed, the hour is coming when everyone who kills you will think he is offering God a service.
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies persecution not just from outsiders but from those who believe themselves to be serving God. See how Saul persecuted the early Church, thinking it zeal.

verses.text: They will do these things because they have not known the Father nor Me.
verses.comment: Ignorance of the Father and of Jesus leads to violence against His followers. Union with Christ and the Father is key to true worship and recognition of God’s will.

verses.text: But I have told you these things so that when their hour comes you may remember that I told them to you. I did not say these things to you from the beginning, because I was with you.
verses.comment: Jesus now openly prepares His disciples for coming trials, as His departure approaches. The emphasis on remembrance reflects the community’s transmission of Jesus’s teaching.

verses.text: But now I am going to Him who sent Me, and yet none of you asks Me, 'Where are You going?'
verses.comment: Jesus returns to the Father who sent Him, underscoring His divine origin (see John 1:1-2). The disciples’ lack of questioning shows their sadness and lack of full understanding.

verses.text: But because I have spoken these things to you, sorrow has filled your hearts.
verses.comment: The disciples are grieved by Jesus’s announced departure, showing their deep love and dependence on Him.

verses.text: Nevertheless, I tell you the truth: it is better for you that I go away. For if I do not go away, the Advocate will not come to you; but if I go, I will send Him to you.
verses.comment: The Advocate—the Holy Spirit—can only come when Christ ascends. This establishes a continuing, authoritative presence guiding the Church in truth. This is significant for the ongoing interpretation of divine revelation.

verses.text: When He comes, He will convict the world concerning sin, and righteousness, and judgment:
verses.comment: The Spirit acts as divine prosecutor, revealing error and drawing people to repentance and truth. The Spirit’s guidance remains essential for the Church’s discernment.

verses.text: concerning sin, because they do not believe in Me;
verses.comment: Unbelief in Jesus as Messiah is the root sin exposed by the Holy Spirit. Faith is foundational for all other virtues.

verses.text: concerning righteousness, because I go to the Father and you will see Me no more;
verses.comment: Christ’s return to the Father affirms His righteousness and divine mission. His resurrection and ascension vindicate His teaching and identity.

verses.text: concerning judgment, because the ruler of this world has been judged.
verses.comment: Satan, the ruler of this world, is condemned; Christ’s victory is announced. The Spirit testifies to the defeat of the enemy and the triumph of Christ.

verses.text: I still have many things to say to you, but you cannot bear them now.
verses.comment: Jesus’s teaching is progressive; more will be revealed as the Church matures through the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: But when He, the Spirit of truth, comes, He will guide you into all the truth. For He will not speak on His own, but will speak whatever He hears, and He will declare to you what is to come.
verses.comment: The Church is promised continual guidance into truth by the Spirit, not private revelation but through the unified body. This grounds the Church’s authority to teach and interpret authentically.

verses.text: He will glorify Me, for He will take from what is Mine and declare it to you.
verses.comment: The Spirit directs all worship and revelation toward Christ, ensuring unity and authentic devotion within the body of believers.

verses.text: All that the Father has is Mine. Therefore I said that the Spirit will take from what is Mine and declare it to you.
verses.comment: This is another indirect claim of divinity: everything belonging to the Father belongs also to Jesus. The Spirit reveals fully divine truth, which the Church receives and hands on.

verses.text: A little while, and you will see Me no more, and again a little while, and you will see Me.
verses.comment: Jesus foretells both His death (the disciples’ loss) and His post-resurrection appearances. The promise is of a continuing presence.

verses.text: Some of His disciples said to one another, 'What is this that He says to us, “A little while, and you will not see Me, and again a little while, and you will see Me,” and “because I am going to the Father”?'
verses.comment: Confusion among the disciples reveals the mysterious nature of Christ’s resurrection and ascension. Full understanding comes later through the Spirit.

verses.text: So they were asking, 'What does He mean by “a little while”? We do not know what He is talking about.'
verses.comment: The disciples’ puzzlement anticipates the moment when the Spirit will clarify Christ’s teaching to the Church.

verses.text: Jesus knew that they wanted to ask Him, so He said to them, 'Are you discussing among yourselves about what I meant, “A little while and you will not see Me, and again a little while and you will see Me”?'
verses.comment: Jesus’s foreknowledge affirms His divinity and insight into human hearts (compare to John 2:25).

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, you will weep and mourn, but the world will rejoice. You will be sorrowful, but your sorrow will turn into joy.
verses.comment: The reversal of sorrow into joy points to the resurrection. The motif of joy after trial is found throughout the Scriptures.

verses.text: When a woman is giving birth, she has sorrow because her hour has come; but when she has delivered the child, she no longer remembers the anguish for joy that a human being has been born into the world.
verses.comment: Childbirth is a consistent biblical metaphor for redemptive suffering. The new life after the resurrection brings transformative joy (see Isaiah 26:17).

verses.text: So also you have sorrow now, but I will see you again, and your hearts will rejoice, and no one will take your joy from you.
verses.comment: Jesus’s appearances after the resurrection are the source of inextinguishable joy for the Church. True joy is rooted in the presence of the risen Lord.

verses.text: In that day you will ask Me nothing. Truly, truly, I say to you, whatever you ask of the Father in My name, He will give you.
verses.comment: Prayer is now offered in Jesus’s name, through His mediation. Participation in His intercession is central to authentic worship.

verses.text: Until now you have asked for nothing in My name. Ask, and you will receive, that your joy may be full.
verses.comment: The unique power of Jesus’s name in prayer is emphasized. Through union with Christ, prayers are guaranteed a hearing and interior joy.

verses.text: I have spoken these things to you in figurative language; but the hour is coming when I will no longer speak to you in figures, but will tell you plainly about the Father.
verses.comment: Jesus often uses figurative language, but after the resurrection, the fullness of revelation is given to the community.

verses.text: In that day you will ask in My name, and I do not say to you that I will ask the Father on your behalf,
verses.comment: The disciples’ relationship to the Father is now transformed through Jesus, allowing direct access to God.

verses.text: for the Father Himself loves you, because you have loved Me and have believed that I came from God.
verses.comment: Love for Jesus and faith in His divine origin opens the way to personal intimacy with the Father.

verses.text: I came from the Father and have come into the world; now I am leaving the world and going to the Father.
verses.comment: A clear affirmation of the Incarnation—Jesus’s preexistence with the Father and His return. This supports high Christology.

verses.text: His disciples said, 'Now You are speaking plainly and not in figurative language.'
verses.comment: The disciples perceive greater clarity in Jesus’s teaching only as the revelation unfolds.

verses.text: Now we know that You know all things and do not need anyone to question You; by this we believe that You came from God.
verses.comment: The disciples acknowledge Christ’s divine omniscience and confirm faith in His heavenly origin.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Do you now believe?'
verses.comment: Jesus tests the depth of their faith, knowing the coming crisis will shake them.

verses.text: Behold, the hour is coming, indeed it has come, when you will be scattered, each to his own home, and will leave Me alone. Yet I am not alone, for the Father is with Me.
verses.comment: Jesus is abandoned by all, but not by the Father; the prophecy of Zechariah 13:7 finds fulfillment here, showing scriptural unity.

verses.text: I have said these things to you so that in Me you may have peace. In the world you will have tribulation; but take heart, I have overcome the world.
verses.comment: Jesus’s victory is the source of lasting peace amidst suffering. The community’s union with Christ assures ultimate triumph, not through individual strength, but by participation in His overcoming the world.
